braided: Strands that usually follow a repetitive over-under pattern
bubbly: Foam or small bubbles forming on the surface
Presence of visible pores or holes
bumpy: **Tactile Impression**: While this is more perceptual, imagining the tactile sensation can help; bumps would feel uneven and rough, whereas grooves would feel ribbed or lined.
chequered: Often seen in contexts such as chessboards or racing flags
High contrast between the alternating colors (often black and white)
cobwebbed: **Fine, thread-like structures:** Cobwebs consist of fine, thread-like strands.
**Lack of distinct structure:** Unlike cobwebs, smears do not have an organized pattern.
cracked: Depth variation: Cracks can vary in depth along their length.
Long, narrow lines or fissures on the surface
Random patterns: Cracks tend to form in irregular, unpredictable patterns.
crosshatched: Indicates texture or shadow in drawings
Material can be metal, fabric, or plastic
Simpler, less textured appearance compared to crosshatching
crystalline: Presence of water or debris in the depressions
dotted: typically seen on fabric or paper for design
Consistent dot size throughout the pattern
Context of use (dotted patterns might be found in different contexts, like technical drawings or textures, while polka dots are more common in clothing and design)
Uniform pattern of separation between dots
uniform size and shape of dots
fibrous: Material composition: Fibrous surfaces are usually found in materials like wood, fabric, or plants that naturally have fibers. Grooved surfaces are more likely to be found in engineered materials like metal, plastic, or some kinds of processed wood.
can show variation in thickness of individual fibers
Fiber direction: Fibrous surfaces will show strands or fibers that may run in various directions, unlike the straight and parallel lines typically found in grooved surfaces.
flecked: No clear lines or breaks in the surface
frilly: Often associated with fabrics or natural elements like flowers
grid: Typically found on roads or pathways
absence of deep depressions or channels
grooved: Consistent and uniform spacing between grooves
Uniformity in spacing and direction of grooves
parallel lines or pattern of the grooves
Horizontal or vertical alignment of grooves
honeycombed: uniform honeycomb grid without interwoven strands
knitted: absence of irregular smudges or streaks
Complex textures like cables or lace
lacelike: "Lacelike" may describe something with an intricate, delicate, and detailed pattern resembling lace.
lined: consistent spacing between the horizontal lines
marbled: Organic, irregular shapes without sharp angles
Appearance of veins or streaks, resembling natural marble
matted: Presence of parallel or patterned indentations
compacted and dense look (for matted hair/fibers)
tangled or clumped appearance (for matted hair/fibers)
meshed: Used in fences, screens, or sieves
Often used for nets or screens
Edge Definition: The edges of holes in perforated materials are well-defined and often sharp, while mesh edges are softer and more blended into the overall pattern.
paisley: Smooth, continuous design without dimensional texture
Generally has a structured, repeating design
Generally solid or with minimal pattern
perforated: Consistent pattern or alignment of holes
Visible symmetry or specific design in the arrangement of holes
pitted: Surface appearance looks like repeated tiny indentations
Presence of irregular, small holes or indentations
Often found on metal or stone surfaces
pleated: Structured appearance: Pleating often gives a more structured and formal look compared to the flat, untextured surface of matted items.
Less uniformity and symmetry compared to pleated structures
polka-dotted: Repetitive dot pattern in various sizes
Usually covers the entire surface or fabric
absence of linear or vertical lines
High contrast between dots and background
porous: Smooth underlying surface with irregular patterns or marks
Surface texture appears rough but uniform
potholed: Irregular, deep indentations or holes in the road surface (potholed)
Gaping holes or depressions in the road surface
scaly: Reflective sheen due to scale texture
smeared: Visible brush strokes or finger marks
spiralled: Clear starting point, usually in the center
sprinkled: no smearing or spreading seen around the particles
varying sizes and shapes of particles
clear distinction between the sprinkled particles and the surface they are on
stained: Presence of a spill or residue
Spreading pattern, often irregular or blotchy
stratified: chaotic or irregular patterns of rock or sediment
mixed and disordered distribution of rock or sediment types
**Smooth and aligned erosion patterns:** Stratified rocks may show smooth, linear erosion patterns following the layers, whereas potholes have rounded, irregular shapes.
studded: Often on objects like belts, clothing, or accessories which typically use studs or rivets
Even distribution over a fabric or material
a more structured and less random overall appearance
swirly: uniform and consistent spacing throughout the curves
veined: Typically found in materials like marble or leaves
**Distinct Lines**: Veined patterns typically have clear, well-defined lines or streaks running through them, resembling the veins in leaves or blood vessels.
woven: Often shows patterns like plaid or herringbone more distinctly
wrinkled: often associated with fabric or skin
patterns akin to crumpled fabric or skin
